text: Equipment used to facilitate underwater diving
label: n

text: Please help improve this article by adding citations to reliable sources . Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.
label: n

label: n

text: Surface supplied commercial diving equipment on display at a trade show
label: n

text: Diving equipment is equipment used by underwater divers to make diving activities possible, easier, safer and or or more comfortable. This may be equipment primarily intended for this purpose, or equipment intended for other purposes which is found to be suitable for diving use.
label: n

text: The fundamental item of diving equipment used by divers is underwater breathing apparatus , such as scuba equipment , and surface-supplied diving equipment, but there are other important pieces of equipment that make diving safer, more convenient or more efficient. Diving equipment used by recreational scuba divers is mostly personal equipment carried by the diver, but professional divers , particularly when operating in the surface supplied or saturation mode , use a large amount of support equipment not carried by the diver.
label: n

text: Equipment which is used for underwater work or other activities which is not directly related to the activity of diving, or which has not been designed or modified specifically for underwater use by divers is excluded.
label: n

text: - mostly used in professional diving. This category includes:
label: n

text: Surface oriented surface supplied diving , where the diver starts and finishes the dive at normal atmospheric pressure.
label: n

text: Saturation diving , where the diver remains under pressure in an underwater habitat or saturation spread between underwater excursions.
label: n

text: surface supplied diving used in the Philippines by artisanal fishermen.
label: n

text: self-contained underwater breathing apparatus. This category includes:
label: n

text: Rebreather diving , closed-circuit or semi-closed-circuit scuba
label: n

text: Free diving or breathhold diving, where the diver completes the dive on a single breath of air taken at the surface before the dive.
label: n

text: Snorkel allows breathing at the surface with the face submerged, and is used as an adjunct to free diving and scuba.
label: n

text: Atmospheric diving suits and other submersibles which isolate the diver from the ambient environment. These are not considered here.
label: n

text: Liquid breathing systems are still hypothetical and at an early experimental stage. It is hoped that some day practical systems will allow very deep diving. This is not considered here.
label: n

text: A US Navy diver at work. The umbilical supplying air from the surface is clearly visible
label: n

text: Diver in standard diving dress entering the water at Stoney Cove, England
label: n

text: Scuba diver with single cylinder and open circuit regulator
label: n

text: The Newtsuit is an atmospheric diving suit which has fully articulated rotary joints in the arms and legs.
label: n

text: This is the diving equipment worn by or carried by the diver for personal protection or comfort, or to facilitate the diving aspect of the activity, and may include a selection from:
label: n

text: Early twin cylinder set with twin hose regulator
label: y

text: Twin scuba cylinders with isolation manifold
label: y

text: Charging a small bailout cylinder from a larger aluminium scuba cylinder
label: y

text: Technical diver with back mounted open circuit scuba and sling mounted decompression cylinders
label: y

text: Diving with a closed circuit rebreather
label: y

text: Heavy standard diving helmet , lightweight demand helmet and band mask
label: y

text: In cold water, a diving suit such as a dry suit , a wet suit , or a Hot water suit is necessary.
label: n

text: Boiler suit overalls are often worn over the thermal protection suit by commercial divers as abrasion protection
label: n

text: In very warm water , many types of tough, long, everyday clothing provide protection, as well as purpose made garments such as dive skins and shorty wetsuits. In some cases, simple regular swimsuits are also used.
label: n

text: Diving gloves , including wetsuit gloves and dry gloves, mitts, and three-finger mitts
label: y

text: Diving boots - With dry suits, the boots are usually integrated.
label: y

text: Diving chain mail may be used as protection against bites by large marine animals
label: y

text: Diver's cages may be used as protection against large predators
label: y

text: Atmospheric diving suit provides complete isolation from the environment
label: n

text: Short and full length wet suits
label: y

text: A backplate is a structure onto which the back-mounted diving cylinders are mounted, usually linking the buoyancy compensator with the weight of the diving cylinders and provided with a harness of straps which secures the scuba set to the diver's back. A backplate is generally used with a back inflation type buoyancy compensator, but can also be used without any buoyancy compensator.
label: y

text: Buoyancy compensator , also known as Buoyancy Control Device, BCD or BC - is usually a back mounted or sleeveless jacket style device which includes an inflatable bladder used to adjust the buoyancy of the diver under water, and provide positive buoyancy at the surface. The buoyancy compensator is usually an integral part of the harness system used to secure the scuba set to the diver. The earlier collar style buoyancy compensator is seldom used any more.
label: y

text: Diving weighting system - to counteract the buoyancy of the diving suit and diver to allow descent. Professional divers may use additional weighting to ensure stability when working on the bottom
label: y

text: Depth gauge lets the diver monitor depth, particularly maximum depth and, when used with a watch and Decompression tables , also allows the diver to monitor decompression requirements. Some digital depth gauges also indicate ascent rate which is an important factor in avoiding decompression sickness
label: n

text: Pneumofathometer is the surface supplied diving depth gauge which displays the depth of the diver at the surface control panel.
label: n

text: Diving watch is used with depth gauge for decompression monitoring when using decompression tables. Largely superseded by dive computers, where elapsed time is one of the standard displays, and time of day may also be available.
label: n

text: Dive timer is an instrument that displays and records depth and elapsed time during the dive. It is usually possible to extract the information after the dive. This function is often available as "Gauge setting" on dive computers.
label: n

text: Submersible pressure gauge , also known as a "contents gauge" is used to monitor the remaining breathing gas supply in scuba cylinders.
label: n

text: Dive computer helps the diver to avoid decompression sickness by indicating the decompression stops needed for the dive profile . Most dive computers also indicate depth, time and ascent rate. Some also indicate oxygen toxicity exposure and water temperature, and may provide other functions. A display of cylinder pressure is available on air-integrated computers, either via a direct high pressure hose, or remotely via a pressure transducer and through-water transmission.
label: n

text: Distance line or "come-home-line" can used to guide the diver back to the start point and safety in poor visibility.
label: n

text: A cave line is a line laid by a diver while penetrating a cave to ensure that the way out is known. Permanent cave lines are marked with line markers at all junctions, indicating the direction along the line toward the nearest exit.
label: n

text: A depth gauge and submersible pressure gauge
label: y

text: A watch sized dive computer incorporating an electronic compass and the ability to display cylinder pressure when used with an optional transmitter
label: y

text: Nav finder and underwater compass - basic underwater navigation tools.
label: y

text: Diving compass in aftermarket wrist mount with bungee straps
label: y

text: A miniature submersible pressure gauge used on pony cylinders
label: y

text: Masks allow the diver to see clearly underwater and protect the eyes.
label: n

text: Full face masks protect the face from dirty or cold water and increases safety by securing the gas supply to the diver's face. If it contains no mouthpiece, the diver can talk, allowing the use of communications equipment.
label: n

text: Half masks cover only the eyes and nose. The diver breathes from a separate mouthpiece on the regulator or rebreather.
label: n

text: Diving helmets are often used with surface supplied diving . They provide the same benefits as the full face mask but provide a very secure connection of the gas supply to the diver and additionally protect the head.
label: n

text: Underwater writing slates and pencils are used to transport pre-dive plans underwater, to record facts whilst underwater and to aid communication with other divers.
label: n

text: Dive lights , which are usually waterproof and pressure rated torches or flashlights , are essential for safety in low visibility or dark environments such as night diving and wreck and cave penetration. They are useful for communication and signalling both underwater and on the surface at night. Divers need artificial light even in shallow and clear water to reveal the red end of the spectrum of light which is absorbed as it travels through water. Underwater video lights can serve the same purpose.
label: n

text: Hand-held sonar for a diver can provide a synthetic view using ultrasonic signals emitted and processed by an electronic device and displayed on a screen.
label: n

text: Ultrasonic signalling devices which attract the buddies attention by vibration have been marketed and may have some limited utility.
label: n

text: A diving half mask provides clear sight and protection
label: y

text: A full face mask covers the eyes, nose and mouth.
label: y

text: One piece LED dive light with soft Goodman type handle
label: y

text: Diver's safety harness , to which a lifeline may be attached, including Bell harness, AR vest, Jump jacket.
label: n

text: to allow the diver to be found by the stand-by diver following the line,
label: n

text: to provide a guideline to the surface control point to guide the diver on return,
label: n

text: to assist the diver to maintain position in a current,
label: n

text: in an emergency, to recover the diver to the surface, and
label: n

text: the divers to people at the surface.
label: n

text: DSMB - , or decompression buoy which is inflated at the start of, or during the ascent, to indicate the position of the divers to the surface team, and as a signal that the divers are ascending.
label: n

text: Knife to cut lines, nets or to pry or dig. Not intended for personal protection against underwater predators as it is generally ineffective for this purpose.
label: n

text: Diver's net or line cutter . This is a small handheld tool carried by scuba divers to extricate themselves if trapped in fishing net or fishing line . It has a small sharp blade such as a replaceable scalpel blade inside the small notch. There is a small hole at the other end for a lanyard to tether the cutter to the diver.
label: n

text: Trauma shears . Very effective as a line cutter, with low risk of inadvertent injury or damage. Usually carried in a pocket or special purpose sheath.
label: n

text: Automatic diver recovery devices which inflate the BCD if the diver stops breathing have been marketed. They are not generally used and the risks may outweigh possible benefits.
label: n

text: this class of personal equipment are to:
label: n

text: allow the support boat to monitor and find divers on the surface during or after a dive
label: n

text: prevent the diver being struck by boat traffic
label: n

text: mark the diver's position when drift diving or while at the decompression stop
label: n

text: help rescue services in lifeboats and helicopters to locate the diver
label: n

text: Surface marker buoy , decompression buoy, delayed SMB, safety sausage or blob
label: y

text: Red or yellow collapsible flag - high visibility, robust, usually stored bungeed to cylinder
label: y

text: Whistle - cheap, will only be heard by people far from engine noise
label: y

text: Torch or flashlight - if at sea after nightfall
label: y

text: High pressure whistle - expensive but effective
label: y

text: Orange dye marker - increases diver's visibility from search helicopters
label: y

text: Mirror such as a used compact disc - to reflect sunlight or searchlights
label: y

text: Emergency locator beacon - A transmitter carried by the diver that can send a GPS position by VHF radio and or or Automatic identification system
label: y

text: Norwegian diving pioneer Odd Henrik Johnsen with underwater camera
label: n

text: Camera , strobe , video lights and housing -
label: y

text: Diving reel , spool or line holder to store and transport a distance line or line for a surface marker buoy. A spool is a small flanged cylinder with an axial hole, around which a length of line can be wound, and a line holder is a flat H-shaped piece of rigid sheet material on which a length of line can be wound, as an alternative to a reel or spool. The line may be used with a surface marker buoy or a delayed surface marker buoy , where negative buoyancy of the spool or line holder will help with unwinding the line underwater.
label: y

text: Dry box to hold objects the diver needs to keep dry at depth
label: n

text: Dry bag to carry items that must stay dry on the boat.
label: y

text: Tool bag to carry tools that may be required
label: y

text: A rescue tether, or rescue rope, is a short lanyard or strap carried by a surface supplied stand-by diver to be used to tether an unresponsive diver to the standby diver during a rescue. It is attached at one end to a D-ring on the stand-by diver's harness, and has a clip at the other end which may be secured to a D-ring on the casualty's harness to allow the rescuer the use of both hands during the return to the bell or surface.
label: y

text: Surface supplied diver rescue tether with soft eye and bolt snap
label: n

text: the Black Sea Fleet in diving equipment SVU-5
label: n

text: A jackstay is a form of guideline laid between two points to guide the diver during a search or to and from the workplace or to support and guide equipment for transport between two points.
label: n

text: Lifting bags , an item of diving equipment consisting of a robust and air-tight bag with straps, which is used to lift heavy objects underwater by means of the bag's buoyancy when filled with air.
label: n

text: A shot line , consisting of a weight, line and buoy , is used to mark the location and identify the ascent and descent point of a dive site, allowing divers to navigate to and from the surface and to do decompression stops at a safe location and to help control rate of ascent and descent.
label: n

text: Decompression trapeze is used to assist in maintaining correct depth during in-water decompression stops.
label: n

text: Diving bells and diving stages are used to transport divers from the surface to the underwater workplace.
label: n

text: A downline is a line from the surface to underwater workplace used to control descent, ascent and the transfer of tools, materials and other equipment between the surface and the workplace.
label: n

text: A weighted version suspended from the surface is used to control working depth when blue-water diving ,
label: n

text: It is similar in function to a jackstay, with an emphasis on the vertical dimension. The terms are largely interchangeable – a downline can be considered a predominantly vertical jackstay.
label: n

text: Boarding ladders , particularly the Christmas tree ladder configuration, with a single central rail and cantilevered rungs on both sides, which allows a diver to climb while wearing fins.
label: y

text: Diver down flag which is flown to warn others that divers are underwater in the vicinity
label: y

text: Diver lifts , to conveniently transport a diver from the deck level into the water near the surface and back out in full equipment.
label: y

text: Diving air compressor to fill diving cylinders with high pressure air or other gasses
label: y

text: Day boats , which may be rigid-hulled inflatable boats
label: y

text: Echo sounder , side-scan sonar and multi-beam sonar for location, depth measurement, and profiling of dive sites
label: y

text: Surface-supplied diving breathing gas supply system, including:
label: n

text: Light and shape signals indicating underwater operations
label: y

text: Surface supply air panels. On the left
label: y

text: A hard-wired diver communications unit mounted in a waterproof box
label: y

text: Personnel Transfer Capsule - a dry bell
label: y

text: Christmas tree style diver's boarding ladder
label: y

text: Remotely operated underwater vehicle - for locating dive sites, observing the environment, conducting visual searches, monitoring divers or performing physical work. Mostly used in professional diving applications.
label: n

text: Life support equipment must be maintained and tested before use to ensure that it remains in serviceable condition and is fit for use at the time. Pre-dive inspection and testing of equipment at some level is standard procedure for all modes and applications of diving. The use of checklists is known to improve reliability of inspection and testing, and may be required by the applicable code of practice or operations manual, or manufacturer's operating instructions. Inadequate pre-dive checks of breathing apparatus can have fatal consequences for some equipment, such as rebreathers , or may require the diving operation to be aborted without achieving its objective.
label: n

text: Planned periodical maintenance, such as annual service and inspection of breathing apparatus, pressure equipment, lifting gear and other items according to manufacturers' recommendations or legislation.
label: n

text: Cleaning and inspection after use, and appropriate storage. A large part of this is washing off salt water to prevent it from drying on the equipment and leaving corrosive brine or abrasive salt deposits, which can cause accelerated deterioration of some materials and jamming of moving parts. The ultraviolet component of sunlight can also damage non-metallic components and equipment, and ozone produced by electrical equipment is known to adversely affect some materials, such as the latex seals on dry suits. Most diving equipment will last better if stored in a cool, dry, well ventilated place out of direct sunlight.
label: n

text: Diving equipment may be exposed to contamination in use and when this happens it must be decontaminated This is a particular issue for hazmat diving , but incidental contamination can occur in other environments. Personal diving equipment shared by more than one user requires disinfection before use. Shared use is common for expensive commercial diving equipment, and for rental recreational equipment, and some items such as demand valves, masks, helmets and snorkels which are worn over the face or held in the mouth are possible vectors for infection by a variety of pathogens . Diving suits are also likely to be contaminated, but less likely to transmit infection directly.
label: n

text: When disinfecting diving equipment it is necessary to consider the effectiveness of the disinfectant on the expected pathogens, and the possible adverse effects on the equipment. Some highly effective methods for disinfection can damage the equipment, or cause accelerated degradation of components due to incompatibility with materials.
label: n
